sentence: Consumer stocks were mostly higher with shares of consumer staples companies in the S&P 500 rising 1.2%.
Shares of consumer discretionary firms in the S&P 500 were up 1.1%.
In company news, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. ( WMT ) rose to an all-time high Friday after reporting a strong start to its holiday sales.
The retailer said it had its second-best day ever for online sales Thursday, with video games, wireless pre-paid phones, HDTVs and baby items among the more popular items sold through its website.
In stores Thursday night, the top five categories for sales, in order, were tablet computers, television, bed sheets, children's apparel and video games.
Separately, the world's largest retailer reportedly was laying off about 30 directors and mid-level managers from its Chinese operations in a bid to contain costs and improve slumping sales.
A spokesman for WMT in China told Marketwatch.com the cuts were part of a broader restructuring effort but declined to provide additional details.

Other retailers - including Target ( TGT ), Macy's ( M ), Home Depot ( HD ), Costco ( COST ), Big Lots (BIG) - reported as much as a 40% jump in Thanksgiving Day sales over year-ago levels, also lifting those shares to record highs.
TGT said its free shipping offer on Target.com "continues to drive record-breaking online sales."
WMT shares were up more than 3% at $87.52 apiece, easing somewhat after a run to a record high of $88.09 a share during the first hour of Friday's session.
Through Wednesday's close, the stock had risen almost 5% over the past 12 months.

(+) JBLU, (+7.7%) Rallies to all-time high as investors bid up airline stocks following a 5% drop in crude oil prices today after OPEC ministers yesterday declined to cut back on member countrys' production.
(+) CTRP, (+1.0%) Turns higher late despite another round of analyst downgrades after earlier this week forecasting Q4 revenue growth likely trailing Q3 levels.
Today's analyst actions include Morgan Stanley cut to Equalweight and JPMorgan downgrade to Neutral.
